definition[0]: feeling pleased about something that you have done or something that you own, or about someone or something you are involved with or related to
example[0]: Seth was the proud owner of a new sports car.
example[1]: The company is justly proud of its achievements.
example[2]: Her parents are very proud of her.
example[3]: You should be proud of yourself.
example[4]: His past record is certainly something to be proud of.
example[5]: Seven-year-old Ian is proud to have earned his red belt in karate.
example[6]: She was proud that the magazine had agreed to publish one of her stories.
explanation[0]: You are proud of someone or something
definition[1]: thinking that you are more important, skilful etc than you really are – used to show disapproval
example[8]: a proud man who would not admit his mistakes
definition[2]: having respect for yourself, so that you are embarrassed to ask for help when you are in a difficult situation
example[9]: Some farmers were too proud to ask for government help.
example[10]: Your family must be very proud of you.
example[11]: He is justifiably proud of what he and his father achieved.
example[12]: They are fiercely proud of their native land.
example[13]: He said he was immensely proud to have been elected prime minister.
example[14]: She was intensely proud of being Japanese.
example[15]: She is now the proud owner of a four-bedroomed house.
example[16]: Mark is the proud father of a three-week-old baby boy.
definition[4]: very pleased with what you, your family, or your country have achieved, or of something you own
example[17]: I felt so proud when my son graduated from college.
example[18]: Judith’s very proud of her new Ferrari.
definition[5]: feeling pleased because something good has happened, especially because you think you have been very clever, skilful etc
example[19]: He was smoking a big cigar and was obviously pleased with himself.
example[20]: I’d made a big profit and was feeling pretty pleased with myself.
definition[6]: behaving in an unpleasant and annoying way, because you think you are better or know more than other people, and that your opinions are always right
example[21]: He was arrogant and regarded people who disagreed with him as fools.
definition[7]: too proud of your appearance, in a way that annoys other people
example[23]: He’s so vain – he thinks all the girls fancy him.
definition[8]: proud of yourself because you think you are very intelligent, skilful, beautiful etc, especially without good reason and in a way that annoys people
example[24]: Stewart’s the most arrogant conceited person I’ve ever known.
example[25]: She was offered a brilliant job and became incredibly big-headed overnight.
definition[9]: thinking that you are much more important than you really are, and using very long and formal words to try to sound important
example[26]: The clerk was a pompous little man with glasses.
definition[10]: pleased with yourself in a quiet but annoying way because you think you are in a better position than other people
example[28]: Milly was looking very smug about coming top of the class.
definition[11]: pleased with what you have achieved and showing it clearly in an annoying way
example[30]: She glared angrily into his self-satisfied face.
